Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: (Jenny) Qiuyun Xiang
co-PI: Robert G. Franks
co-PI: DeYu Xie
IOS - 1024629
Evolution of Floral Display Strategies in Dogwoods - A Synergistic Approach to Explore the Developmental and Molecular Mechanisms

Variation in the arrangement of flowers (i.e. the inflorescence architecture) affects the yield of many crop species by influencing the number of seeds and fruits and the ability to harvest the crop. Despite the importance of inflorescence architecture to humankind, little progress has been made in understanding how developmental and genetic changes have shaped inflorescence architectures in the diversity of flowering plants on earth. Species of Dogwood (Cornus L.) are popular ornamental trees in American landscapes due to their spectacular inflorescences. In addition to being beautiful, the genus Cornus offers us a unique opportunity to understand the evolution and development of different inflorescence architectures. Different Dogwood species exhibit a wide variation in inflorescence structures. In this project this interdisciplinary team of scientists will apply molecular and developmental approaches to understand the molecular basis for the diversification of inflorescence architecture in the Dogwood species. This greater understanding of the molecular mechanisms of inflorescence development and evolution may enable efforts to breed agricultural varieties with inflorescence structures to allow greater agricultural productivity. The primary investigators of this project are also involved in a K-12 school outreach program in which members of this research team lead demonstrations at local grade schools, thus promoting scientific literacy at this early age.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project identified key evolutionary changes of developmental morphology that explain to the origin of the condensed inflorescence form (i.e., umbels and heads) from elongated, complex inflorescence within the dogwood genus Cornus L.. The morphological changes were found to co-occur with changes in the transcription pattern and level of Terminal Flower Locus I (TFL1)-like (CorTFL1) and APETALA I (AP1)-like (CorAP1) genes in Cornus. Expression duration and level of CorTFL1 and CorAP1, but not CorLFY, were correlated with the inflorescence types.

Stable genetic transformation system was established for C. canadensis and used for gene functional analyses. Overexpression of CorTFL1 from C. candensis and C. florida in model plant Arabidopsis resulted in delay of flowering, prolonged vegetative growth, and extra branching of inflorescences , as well as rescue of the wild phenotype of the mutant. Down regulating the expression of CorTFL1 in Cornus canadensis led to delay of flowering or abnormal of inflorescence morphology in some transgenic plants.  Earlier flowering was observed in C. candensis with LEAFY-like gene (CorLFY) overexpressed. Evidence together indicate an important role of CorLFY, CorTFL1, and CorAP1 in the inflorescence development of the Cornus kinds (determinate, closed by a terminal flower), but CorTFL1 and CorAP1 may hold a key to the question of origin of the dramatic differences of inflorescence architectures within Cornus.

Petaloid bracts in C. florida and C. canadensis were found to have different developmental origins although their microscopic morphology is similar to that of petals at the mature stage. Petal organ identify genes (i.e., PISTILLATA-like gene (CorPI-B) and APETALA 3-like (CorAP3)) were found to involve in the initiations of petal and stamen, but not the initiation of bracts. However, CorPI-B expression was found to be involved in the expansion of bracts in C. florida. We also found evidence of co-evolution between CorAP3 and CorPI genes in Cornus. Down-regulating the expression of CorcanAP3 in C. canadensis resulted in the loss of a critical floral structure (the “x”-form floral bud built with mechanical energy) for explosive pollen release due to delayed petal and stamen development. Stigma-like anther and extra small bracts and extra inflorescence branches were also observed in some transgenic plants. The evidence supports the role of CorAP3 in petal and stamen development, and suggests that the gene may also have a role in regulating bract and inflorescence development that can be tested in future studies.

The project resulted in 13 publications in peer-reviewed journals [10 directly supported by the grant  (two are in revision) and 3 were indirectly benefitted from the grant], 12 invited symposium or seminar talks, 15 conference oral presentations, 6 conference posters, one symposium on the project topic in 2016 BSA conference, professional training of 2 Ph.D., 1 postdoc, 1 technician, 13 undergraduate students, 10 visiting students/faculty via research in the lab, and botany training of many students through the study abroad course and classroom teaching every year. In addition, project resulted in a stable genetic transformation system of C. candensis and a variety of transgenic plants that are valuable for study of gene functions or for genetic manipulation to generate new varieties of horticulture interest. Through collaboration with Chinese colleagues, the project was expanded beyond the original funded scope.
